docs.lead_paragraph: After suffering days of Republican barbs in silence, Vice President Al Gore returned from vacation today swinging back hard, accusing the Republicans of running a showy, but insubstantial convention and strongly claiming credit for having helped create the nation's roaring economy. Mr. Gore had spent the week with his family on a North Carolina beach while the newly minted Republican ticket of Gov. George W. Bush and Dick Cheney used the stage in Philadelphia to portray the Clinton administration as timid, ineffectual and lacking vision.

headline.main: GORE FIRES BACK, HOPING TO DAMPEN CONVENTION SPIRIT

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore roars back into presidential campaign after a week's vacation, giving speech to International Association of Fire Fighters in Chicago in which defends himself against the barbs hurled at him at National Republican Convention and delivers a few of his own; accuses Republicans of running a showy, but insubstantial, convention; claims credit for helping create the nation's roaring economy when he cast a tie-breaking vote in Senate for president's 1993 economic stimulus package; photo (M)
docs.snippet: After suffering days of Republican barbs in silence, Vice President Al Gore returned from vacation today swinging back hard, accusing the Republicans of running a showy, but insubstantial convention and strongly claiming credit for having helped...

docs.lead_paragraph: Maine certainly fired the first shot. Under a law passed in May, it became the first state to threaten the pharmaceutical industry with price controls on prescription drugs, and it created a program to negotiate lower prices for about half its residents. But now, it appears, the pharmaceutical industry is beginning to fire back. SmithKline Beecham, the drug manufacturer, said today that concerns about the new law's potential effects were prompting it to shift its supply routes and that it would now ship its drugs directly only to wholesalers based in other states.

headline.main: Drug Maker Fires Back At Maine Over Law

docs.abstract: Pharmaceutical industry strikes back at Maine, which enacted law in May that threatened industry with price controls on prescription drugs and created program to negotiate lower prices for about half its residents; SmithKline Beecham says law's potential effects are prompting it to ship its drugs directly only to wholesalers in other states (M)
docs.snippet: Maine certainly fired the first shot. Under a law passed in May, it became the first state to threaten the pharmaceutical industry with price controls on prescription drugs, and it created a program to negotiate lower prices for about half its...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York announced yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its troubled Florida subsidiary to a group of health companies. Officials at HIP would not disclose the price. But business analysts estimated that HIP would recover only a fraction of the $80 million that it had invested in the subsidiary.

headline.main: Metro Business; HIP to Sell Unit To H.M.O. Group

docs.abstract: Health Insurance Plan of Greater Ne York will sell troubled Florida subsidiary to group of companies led by Dr Steven C Scott (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton received the endorsement of Planned Parenthood today and used the occasion to exhaustively criticize her Senate opponent, Representative Rick A. Lazio, for his position on abortion and for what she implied was his petulant reaction to her attacks. ''When you say something that's accurate about someone's record, if they don't want anybody to know about it, they say it's negative,'' Mrs. Clinton told a group of several hundred people at the State University of New York here.

headline.main: Mrs. Clinton Criticizes Lazio on 'Multiple Choice' Abortion Stance

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation, the nation's third-largest health insurer, said today that its second-quarter profit rose 11 percent, beating expectations, as it signed more customers, held costs down and raised premiums. Cigna said profit from continuing operations rose to $279 million, or $1.71 a share, compared with $251 million, or $1.22 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue rose 6 percent, to $4.97 billion from $4.69 billion. Analysts had expected Cigna to earn $1.56 a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.

headline.main: Rise in Customers and Prices Lifts Cigna's Profits by 11%

docs.abstract: Cigna Corp says second-quarter profit rose 11 percent to $279 million, compared with year earlier $251 million, beating expectations (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Call it the big sell. The Borough of Manhattan Community College is plastering its name all over New York City -- in 350 buses, 1,000 subway cars and 24 movie theaters, to be exact -- to attract students, and is sending current students out on the streets to recruit. Ronald Spalter, the college's vice president for administration and planning, is even planning to send students to Jones Beach to collar prospects for this fall's class right on the sands.

headline.main: College Takes to Street to Drum Up Enrollment

docs.abstract: City University of New York begins heavily marketing its six community colleges after the number of applicants in the late spring falls more than 10 percent below 1999; some CUNY professors suggest that students feel unwelcome because of new policies limiting remedial classes; CUNY administrators disagree, noting that those changes affect only senior colleges and attributing application decline to booming economy, which makes work more attractive than school; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Call it the big sell.    The Borough of Manhattan Community College is plastering its name all over New York City -- in 350 buses, 1,000 subway cars and 24 movie theaters, to be exact -- to attract students, and is sending current students out on the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Accusing the Republican Party of using its convention to mask Gov. George W. Bush's stands on controversial issues, Democrats and groups with close ties to them are unleashing commercials that criticize his record in Texas as well as his positions on gun control and abortion. The groups -- Planned Parenthood, Handgun Control and the Sierra Club -- are all running commercials singling out Mr. Bush in a week in which Republicans are staging a convention that was intended to sidestep divisive topics like abortion.

headline.main: Democrats Join With Allies In Piling on Bush's Record

docs.abstract: Democrats and their allies, accusing Republican Party of using its convention to mask Gov George W Bush's deeply conservative stands on controversial issues, are unleashing commercials that criticize his record; biggest barrage is coming from Democratic National Committee, which has been releasing at least one new ad each day and plans to continue doing so (M)
docs.snippet: Accusing the Republican Party of using its convention to mask Gov. George W. Bush's stands on controversial issues, Democrats and groups with close ties to them are unleashing commercials that criticize his record in Texas as well as his positions on...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your July 26 editorial ''Driving Up Drug Prices'' urges a case-by-case approach to the complex questions surrounding patent laws, food and drug laws, and competition policy expressed in the Hatch-Waxman Act. You then suggest that Andrx Pharmaceuticals intended to delay generic competition by entering into an agreement in connection with its continuing patent infringement litigation. We did not, and in fact, as a result of the agreement, consumers got Andrx's lower-priced generic product faster than they would have otherwise.
docs.abstract: Letter from Andrx Pharmaceuticals general counsel, Scott Lodin, disputes July 26 editorial on rise in prescription drug prices
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Your July 26 editorial ''Driving Up Drug Prices'' urges a case-by-case approach to the complex questions surrounding patent laws, food and drug laws, and competition policy expressed in the Hatch-Waxman Act. You then suggest that...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Prescription for Failure,'' by Paul Krugman (column, July 26): The only way to provide affordable prescription drug coverage for all is to pool the burden as widely as possible in a single-payer health care system that provides universal coverage. The for-profit insurance industry has no motive to cover the sickest people because it makes no business sense.
